recipes.title: Afia Makes Jollof Rice!
recipes.intro: Let's cook something yummy from Ghana with Afia and her family!
recipes.introFact: Jollof is loved across West Africa!
recipes.completionMessage: Ta-da! Your jollof rice is ready to share.
recipes.completionFact: Families cook jollof for celebrations and special days.

steps.story: First, we rinse the rice so it's nice and clean!
steps.fact: Splash splash! Clean rice helps make fluffy jollof.

steps.story: Now let's chop tomatoes and onions!
steps.fact: Nice chopping! Tomatoes and onions build flavor.

steps.story: Pour a little oil into the pot.
steps.fact: Glug glug! A little oil helps everything cook smoothly.

steps.story: Tomato time! This makes jollof yummy and red.
steps.fact: Tomatoes grow in many places in Ghana.

steps.story: Let's add pepper and spices. Just a little!
steps.fact: Sprinkle sprinkle! Spices make jollof extra tasty.

steps.story: Stir in a big circle so it doesn't stick!
steps.fact: Big circles help blend all the flavors.

steps.story: Now pour in the rice!
steps.fact: The pot is getting full and ready.

steps.story: Hold the lid gently... shhh... it's cooking!
steps.fact: Soft steam means dinner is almost ready.

recipes.title: Waakye
recipes.intro: Afia and her uncle are preparing waakye for a busy market morning.
recipes.completionMessage: Waakye is served and everyone is excited to eat!

steps.story: Tap to wash rice and beans.
steps.fact: Waakye mixes rice and beans in one meal.

steps.story: Drag spices into the pot.
steps.fact: Spices make every family recipe unique.

steps.story: Stir everything together.
steps.fact: Stirring helps mix the rice and beans evenly.

steps.story: Hold to finish cooking.
steps.fact: Waakye is popular for breakfast and lunch.

recipes.title: Banku & Tilapia
recipes.intro: Afia is making banku and grilled tilapia with her dad by the beach.
recipes.completionMessage: Banku and tilapia are plated perfectly!

steps.story: Tap to mix the dough.
steps.fact: Banku is made from fermented corn and cassava dough.

steps.story: Drag fish onto the grill.
steps.fact: Tilapia is often served with pepper and onions.

steps.story: Stir the banku gently.
steps.fact: Gentle stirring keeps the texture smooth.

steps.story: Hold to finish grilling.
steps.fact: Grilled fish is a favorite in many coastal towns.

recipes.title: Kelewele
recipes.intro: Afia is making spicy kelewele for an evening snack.
recipes.completionMessage: Golden kelewele cubes are ready to share!

steps.story: Tap to season the plantain cubes.
steps.fact: Kelewele is made with ripe plantains.

steps.story: Drag cubes into the pan.
steps.fact: Ginger and pepper add bold flavor.

steps.story: Stir so they cook evenly.
steps.fact: Even stirring helps each cube turn golden.

steps.story: Hold to finish and caramelize.
steps.fact: Kelewele is a popular evening snack.

recipes.title: Fried Rice
recipes.intro: Afia helps stir colorful fried rice for lunch.
recipes.completionMessage: Fried rice is done and smells amazing!

steps.story: Tap to prepare the vegetables.
steps.fact: Colorful vegetables add crunch and vitamins.

steps.story: Drag rice and veggies into the wok.
steps.fact: Mixing ingredients helps flavor every bite.

steps.story: Stir quickly in circles.
steps.fact: Quick stirring keeps rice from sticking.

steps.story: Hold to steam for a moment.
steps.fact: A short steam makes the rice soft and warm.

recipes.title: Afia Pounds Fufu!
recipes.intro: Afia and her grandma are pounding fufu together — it takes teamwork and strong arms!
recipes.introFact: Fufu is one of the most loved foods in Ghana — families make it together!
recipes.completionMessage: Smooth, stretchy fufu with hot soup — the perfect meal!
recipes.completionFact: You swallow fufu without chewing — it slides right down into your tummy!

steps.story: Tap to chop the cassava and plantain into pieces!
steps.fact: Fufu is made from cassava and plantain boiled together!

steps.story: Drag the pieces into the big pot to boil!
steps.fact: The pieces need to be very soft before pounding.

steps.story: Pound the fufu in the mortar — tap hard!
steps.fact: One person pounds while another turns the dough — teamwork!

steps.story: Stir the light soup with tomatoes and chicken!
steps.fact: Light soup or groundnut soup are the best partners for fufu!

steps.story: Hold to let the soup simmer until it’s perfect!
steps.fact: The pounding sound can be heard across the neighbourhood!

recipes.title: Afia’s Morning Koko!
recipes.intro: Good morning! Afia is making warm koko porridge for a cosy breakfast!
recipes.introFact: Koko is a warm porridge that Ghanaian families eat for breakfast every day!
recipes.completionMessage: Warm, spicy koko with bread — the best breakfast!
recipes.completionFact: Koko is often sold by women carrying big pots on their heads at the market!

steps.story: Tap to grind the millet into a smooth paste!
steps.fact: Koko is made from fermented millet or corn!

steps.story: Drag the millet paste into the pot of hot water!
steps.fact: Fermenting the grain gives koko its special tangy taste!

steps.story: Stir the porridge until it’s thick and smooth!
steps.fact: You need to stir constantly so it doesn’t get lumpy!

steps.story: Tap to add sugar and ginger for extra flavour!
steps.fact: Ginger makes koko warm and spicy — perfect for chilly mornings!

recipes.title: Afia Makes Peanut Butter Soup!
recipes.intro: Afia and her auntie are making the creamiest peanut butter soup for the whole family!
recipes.introFact: Peanut butter soup is also called groundnut soup — and it’s one of Ghana’s favourites!
recipes.completionMessage: Thick, creamy peanut butter soup — everyone wants seconds!
recipes.completionFact: Peanut butter soup is one of the most popular soups in all of Ghana!

steps.story: Tap to crush the peanuts into a smooth paste!
steps.fact: Grinding the peanuts into paste is what makes the soup so creamy!

steps.story: Drag the tomatoes and onions into the pot!
steps.fact: Tomatoes and onions build the rich base of the soup!

steps.story: Stir the peanut paste into the soup!
steps.fact: The paste slowly dissolves and makes the soup thick and orange!

steps.story: Hold to let the soup cook low and slow!
steps.fact: Peanut butter soup is best eaten with fufu or rice balls!

recipes.title: Afia’s Palm Nut Soup!
recipes.intro: Afia is helping her grandma make traditional palm nut soup — it’s been in the family for generations!
recipes.introFact: Palm nut soup is one of the oldest traditional recipes in Ghana!
recipes.completionMessage: Rich, orange palm nut soup — a taste of Ghana’s history!
recipes.completionFact: The beautiful orange colour comes from the oil inside the palm fruits!

steps.story: Tap to pound the boiled palm fruits!
steps.fact: Palm fruits grow in big bunches on tall palm trees!

steps.story: Drag the palm cream into the pot with the meat!
steps.fact: The rich cream is squeezed out of the pounded palm fruits!

steps.story: Stir the soup as it bubbles and thickens!
steps.fact: The soup turns a beautiful deep orange colour as it cooks!

steps.story: Hold to let the soup simmer until the oil rises to the top!
steps.fact: Palm nut soup is eaten with fufu, rice balls, or boiled yam!
